title: Attempt to fix intermittent problems playing sounds.
message:
Attempt to fix intermittent problems playing sounds.

Sounds usually work, but then sometimes, for reasons that have
not been ascertained, they stop with an IOException. This
problem occurs quite regularly on a real handset, but has never
occurred in the emulator.

The phone log (obtained over USB with ddms) contains the entries:
  WARN/PlayerDriver(16515): PVMFInfoErrorHandlingComplete
  WARN/MediaPlayer(16634): info/warning (1, 26)
  ERROR/PlayerDriver(16515): Command PLAYER_SET_DATA_SOURCE
	    completed with an error or info PVMFErrNotSupported
  ERROR/MediaPlayer(16634): error (1, -4)

title: Eliminate another race condition.
message:
Eliminate another race condition.

This one can be triggered by launching Mnemododo, and then, very
quickly, pressing the Home button while the "loading statistics"
dialog is displayed. Mnemododo will then crash on restart (even
in the emulator).

title: Work around a race condition on resume.
message:
Work around a race condition on resume.

This code worked on the assumption that the application object
would be resumed before any of the child threads, thus allowing
it to call updateCallback() before onPostExecute(). This always
seemed to work on the emulator, but the phone crashed sometimes.
Using usb debugging I traced the error to a null pointer (on
callback) in onPostExecute(). This patch works around the
problem by caching the result if it is retrieved before a
callback object is specified.

title: Tidy up callbacks from ProgressTasks.
message:
Tidy up callbacks from ProgressTasks.

Shift more of the logic for handling pausing and resuming of
asynchronous tasks into the ProgressTask class, and update the
subclasses appropriately. The implementation is still ugly, but
it seems a bit better than before.

The problem is that we need to work with the latest copy of an
Application or Settings class in the code that is executed when
a ProgressTask completes. And these classes may have been
destroyed and recreated in the meantime (due to pause and
resume).
